comments:
btw, this is on 3.1M5A, both win32 and linux.

Not sure what causes the exception, but it should be handled without the search
failing.

java.nio.charset.IllegalCharsetNameException: (db encoding)
        at java.nio.charset.Charset.checkName(Charset.java:285)
        at java.nio.charset.Charset.lookup2(Charset.java:459)
        at java.nio.charset.Charset.lookup(Charset.java:438)
        at java.nio.charset.Charset.forName(Charset.java:497)
        at
org.eclipse.search.internal.core.text.TextSearchVisitor.visit(TextSearchVisitor.java:191)
        at
org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Resource$1.visitElement(Resource.java:52)
        at
org.eclipse.core.internal.watson.ElementTreeIterator.doIteration(ElementTreeIterator.java:81)
        at
org.eclipse.core.internal.watson.ElementTreeIterator.doIteration(ElementTreeIterator.java:85)
        at
org.eclipse.core.internal.watson.ElementTreeIterator.doIteration(ElementTreeIterator.java:85)
        at
org.eclipse.core.internal.watson.ElementTreeIterator.doIteration(ElementTreeIterator.java:85)
        at
org.eclipse.core.internal.watson.ElementTreeIterator.doIteration(ElementTreeIterator.java:85)
        at
org.eclipse.core.internal.watson.ElementTreeIterator.doIteration(ElementTreeIterator.java:85)
        at
org.eclipse.core.internal.watson.ElementTreeIterator.iterate(ElementTreeIterator.java:126)
        at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Resource.accept(Resource.java:62)
        at
org.eclipse.search.internal.core.text.TextSearchVisitor.process(TextSearchVisitor.java:105)
        at
org.eclipse.search.internal.core.text.TextSearchEngine.search(TextSearchEngine.java:76)
        at
org.eclipse.search.internal.core.text.TextSearchEngine.search(TextSearchEngine.java:47)
        at
org.eclipse.search.internal.ui.text.FileSearchQuery.run(FileSearchQuery.java:82)
        at
org.eclipse.search2.internal.ui.InternalSearchUI$InternalSearchJob.run(InternalSearchUI.java:93)
        at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:67)

Search does only fail for the file with the problem. All other files will be
searched and you get the problem(s) reported in the end.

I don't think we can do better than that. It's not possible to read a file if
its encoding is unknown to us.

Reopen if you observe something else.

Look at the exception.  Unless the code has changed since the 3.1m5a release
there's no way it can work for you - there's no catch block for the
IllegalCharsetNameException in TextSearchVisitor.java.  I can't send you an
example file that exhibits this (company confidential and all), but if i add the
catch block then it works fine (I can send you the code for the fix if you
like).  Frankly, i think its wrong that those functions throw unchecked
exceptions, but hey its your code base.

You are right. Thanks. I wasn't aware of the IllegalCharsetNameException.
fixed > 20050308
